Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Salicylic acid signaling in plant pathogen interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
During their lifetime plants face many kinds of abiotic and biotic stresses. Major threats include fungal, oomycete, viral, bacterial and nematode pathogens. It is estimated that diseases caused by these plant pathogens reduce plant yield by 10-20% every year. Over millions of years of molecular interactions and co-evolution of host plants and their pathogens, plants developed a sophisticated immune system that senses an impending infection and organizes appropriate defense responses. A key and essential player in this process is the hormone salicylic acid (SA). Although receiving considerable attention from the research community, essential aspects of its role in immunity remain unknown. This project seeks to resolve fundamental new mechanisms through which this major immune regulator achieves its effects. These may provide new strategies for developing disease resistant crop plants.

As a master regulator of plant defense, the protein NPR1 is required for SA-mediated systemic acquired resistance (SAR) and basal defense. In the absence of pathogens or SA treatment, most NPR1 exists in the cytosol as oligomers. After pathogen challenge or SA treatment, NPR1 oligomers are reduced to monomers which enter the nucleus where they function as transcriptional coactivators, binding TGA transcription factors to activate the expression of plant defense genes. Recent publications demonstrated that NPR1 and its paralogs NPR3 and NPR4 bind SA with different affinities and function as SA receptors. In addition, the PI has identified HEN3, a nuclear kinase which is required for NPR1 monomer formation, plant defense gene expression and SAR. Significantly, SA promotes interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4 transcription factors in a yeast two-hybrid assay, thus supporting the hypothesis that SA and NPR1 activate plant defense through increased protein-protein interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4. This project seeks to resolve molecular mechanisms that underlie and regulate the function of this key immune signaling hub. Mechanisms to be explored include the role of the HEN3 kinase in regulating NPR1 function, and the effect of SA on interactions between NPR1/3/4 and TGA1/4. The broader impacts of the project include the participation of a postdoc, a graduate student and four undergraduates, including two from groups underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant diseases caused by pant pathogens reduce crop yield by 10-15% worldwide every year. Pathogen infection induces the production of the plant defense hormone salicylic acid (SA). NPR1 (Non-Expresser of PR Genes 1) was identified through genetic screens for Arabidopsis mutants that are abolished in the expression of PR (Pathogenesis-Related) genes, which encode proteins with antibiotic activities. NPR1 protein binds SA and functions as an SA receptor. The expression of over 98% of SA-regulated genes is dependent on NPR1. Therefore, NPR1 is a master regulator of plant defense. NPR1 interacts with TGA transcription factors in the nucleus to activate the expression of PR genes. Despite many years of research, we still have limited understanding on the regulation of NPR1 protein. More importantly, we still do not know how NPR1, TGA and SA facilitate the expression of PR genes. Our preliminary data showed that the CDK8 homolog in Arabidopsis HEN3 kinase is required for the accumulation of NPR1 protein and systemic acquired resistance. In addition, we found that SA promotes the interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4.

 

After our project is funded by this NSF, we showed that treatment of hen3 knockout plants with the 26S proteasome inhibitor MG115 increases NPR1 protein level suggesting NPR1 protein level in hen3 knockout plants is degraded by the 26S proteasome. We proved that HEN3 is required for nuclear localization of NPR1 protein after SA treatment. We provided evidence that SP site phosphorylation of NPR1 is partially dependent on HEN3.  HEN3 (CDK8), Cyclin C, MED12 and MED13 form the detachable module of the mediator complex. Interestingly, we found that the HEN3/MED12/MED13 complex, but not Cyclin C is required for the stability of NPR1 protein and establishment of SAR. On regulation of the interactions between NPR1 and TGA transcription factors by SA, we showed that SA promotes the interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4, but not the interactions between NPR1 and TGA2/3/5/6/7. Only active SA analogs promote the interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4, while the SA inactive 3-HBA (3-hydroxylbenzoic acid) has no effect indicating that effect of SA to promote the interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4 is specific. Using purified NPR1 and TGA1/4 proteins, we found that the direct interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4 are promoted by SA. NPR1 interacts with TGA4 C terminus with and without SA at least 100 times stronger than with the full length TGA4 in the presence of SA suggesting that deletion of N terminus of TGA4 caused TGA4 to adopt a new conformation that favors its interaction with NPR1. Many BTB domain proteins function as adaptors for Cullin 3 E3 ligase. We found that NPR1 as a BTB domain containing protein directly interacts with CUL3A in in vitro pull down assay suggesting that NPR1 functions as an adaptor protein for the cullin3 E3 ligase. It has been shown that a yeast F-box protein called Dsg1/Mdm30 functions as an adaptor protein for CUL1 E3 ligase to promote the degradation of GAL4 transcription factor. Surprisingly, this degradation facilitates the expression of GAL4 target genes. We are investigating NPR1-dependent ubiquitination and degradation of TGA transcription factors and determining the relationship between PR gene expression and NPR1-dependent degradation of TGA transcription factors.

 

The HEN3 homolog in human CDK8 is an oncogene. NPR1 is functional equivalent to NF-KappaB in mammalian system. Our study could shed light on medical science and cancer biology. By showing that SA promotes the interactions between NPR1 and TGA1/4, we revealed novel functions of three major players in plant defense: SA, NPR1, and TGA transcription factors. Furthermore, the exact function of SA receptor, NPR1, remains unknown. We aim to prove that NPR1 functions as an adaptor for CUL3 E3 ligase, which mediates the degradation of TGA transcription factors. We believe that this degradation facilitates the expression of PR genes. This novel mechanism of gene activation, which is based on both hormone-dependent and -independent interactions between hormone receptors and transcription factors, and is dependent on the degradation of transcription factors by CUL3 E3 ligase, has not been reported before, and could shed light on gene regulation in many other systems. SA is well known as the active ingredient of aspirin. We believe that salicylates have broad medical uses, which could be attributed to the fact that SA affects protein-protein interactions.

 

For the HEN3 project, we are preparing a manuscript to summarize our data. The data we obtained on regulation of PR gene expression by SA-dependent and –independent interactions between NPR1 and TGA transcription factors were used in our application for an NSF PBI (Plant Biotic Interaction) grant. This project has supported 2 undergraduates, 2 graduate students (summer only) and 1 postdoc. I have given exciting presentations on plant pathogens and plant diseases to over 100 students at the Meadow Glenn Middle and the Meadow Glenn Elementary schools in the Lexington county of South Carolina.
